greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle T(n,k), n>=1, 1<=k<=n, read by rows: T(n,k) is the number of positive integers j<k such that j,k,n are pairwise coprime.
comment: T(n,k) = A000010(k) if n is prime and 1<k<n.
link: Alois P. Heinz, Rows n = 1..250, flattened
formula: T(n,k) = |{ j : 1 <= j < k and GCD(n,k) = GCD(n,j) = GCD(k,j) = 1 }|.
example: T(n,1) = 0 because no positive integer j<1 can be found.
T(7,5) = 4 because for j in {1,2,3,4} all conditions are satisfied.
maple: T:= proc(n,k) local c, i, j, m;
if k=1 or igcd(n, k)>1 then 0
for j to k-1 by i do
if igcd(m, j)=1 then c:= c+1 fi
mathematica: t[n_, k_] := Module[{c, i, j, m}, If[ k == 1 || GCD[n, k] > 1, 0, If[PrimeQ[n], EulerPhi[k], m = n*k; i = GCD[m, 2]; c = 0; For[j = 1, j <= k-1, j = j+i, If[GCD[m, j] == 1, c = c+1]]; c]]]; Table[Table[t[n, k], {k, 1, n}], {n, 1, 20}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Dec 19 2013 *)
xref: Row sums give: A185953. Column k=2 gives: A000035 for n>1. Lower diagonal gives: A057475(n-1) for n>2. Cf. A000010, A000040, A003989.
results.author: _Alois P. Heinz_, Feb 15 2011
